title: Friday, 19th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
BE11:00am

Good morning, hey, hello, hi there.

Mouselet Insert your slightly off-colour Dignity metaphor here
BE11:01am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live thing with the live markets and whatnot.

BE11:01am

Picture, then.

Blank canvas morning all
11:01 am
BE11:01am

Soundbuy Morning
Manxish Morning
Mouselet also, good morning on this day where one is reminded how FTSE100 trackers have the advantage of being forced to sell the kind of companies that discover everything is full of cockroaches when they're in the FTSE250
BE11:01am

That (minus the pointer, which I seem to have left in the image) is Euroroute.

BE11:01am

One of four shortlisted designs for how to link England to France, and obviously the best one.

11:01 am
BE11:02am

A hybrid bridge-tunnel thing, involving two artificial islands with corkscrew junctions on top.

Mouselet The aspirational housing next to a Little Chef and a giant spiral ramp full of lorries, in the middle of the sea.
NH11:02am

Morning all

Markkus Morning
NH11:02am

So that's what a Boris Bridge would look like

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Aha! Morning, Neil. Good of you to join us. It could!

casapinos is it a "Brunnel?"
BE11:03am

There's a great article about Euroroute here: http://www.cbrd.co.uk/articles/euroroute

BE11:03am

Explaining that it'd be a wildly expensive folly, but still pretty cool.

Mouselet I am almost willing to start accepting the view that Boris is a Trump-like distraction, saying journalist-exciting things when wanting to distract from complicated EU policy issues
11:03 am
NH11:03am

Will take a look

Kiwi-juice the Chunnel is 1/3 full and they want a bridge?
BE11:03am

So clearly, this is the plan we have to resurrect to show the world that they have a force to be reckoned with in The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Maybe Northern Ireland If We can Figure Out That Whole Thing in Time.

Mouselet "Wildly expensive folly but pretty cool" is what the Gulf States are for, isn't it?
undefined
Swedish chef Morning muppet friends. Note Channel tunnel runs at <60% capacity.
Mouselet If you're going to build a daft bridge, at least build it to Northern Ireland!
kim Do you have a picture of an oil tanker, to give a sense of scale?
11:03 am
NH11:04am

Could it be a PFI project?

TheManwithaLongChin What is it about Boris and bridges?
BE11:04am

No, I was kinda hoping it would get finished .....

NH11:04am

Anyway

11:04 am
NH11:04am

lots to talk about for a Friday

Mouselet ( ponders whether today is a good day to top up HICL ... )
BE11:04am

Fairly busy, yes. Where to begin?

Swedish chef KLM A big red bus would be a better indication of scale, and £350 million a price comparison
NH11:04am

death

Alchemy30 Morning, IWG weak
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Yup. I guess we could begin at the end, so to speak.

Dignity PLC (DTY:LSE): Last: 986.00, down 930 (-48.54%), High: 1,200, Low: 874.50, Volume: 5.74m
NH11:05am

wow

Mouselet eight working days before we talk about taxes
11:05 am
NH11:05am

not often you see 50 per cent wiped off a mid cap in a morning

BE11:05am

Particularly when they were known issues .....

Soundbuy Tad windy at times.............
NH11:06am

So that is the problem with the UK funeral market?

11:05 am
NH11:06am

not enough people dying

NH11:06am

in which case to we blame the old

BE11:06am

Nah. Wheels falling off the hearse.

Lefevre Is the muppet ban still in place? Someones twitter photo seems to breach it
Mouselet didn't one of the short-sellers file on them a month or so back with a target of very little?
11:06 am
NH11:06am

or overcapacity

h1 DFS Furniture and Carpetright @BE @NH
BE11:06am

Death rates are what they are. Death is fairly constant, give or take the odd cold winter.

doeswalk or flu pandemic
Swedish chef Thought Macron had the air of an undertaker looking forward to a particularly hard winter yesterday.
NH11:07am

So this is people realising that they are being fleeced at the graveyard?

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Yup. What Dignity did was buy up a load of local funeral directors and use that market share to push up prices.

NH11:07am

and there's been a backlash?

BE11:07am

Them and Co-op formed a little sort of cartel.

11:07 am
NH11:07am

what does a simply funeral retail at?

BE11:07am

Internet happened.

BornCynic Good morning to a muppet free zone.
BE11:08am

I'd have to check, having not bought one for a while thankfully, but the gist here is that Dignity squeezed prices up so much that it attracted new entrants .....

BornCynic Can I point out that you might want to change the name of the "Smart Money" column - smart money means that there is dumb money............
11:08 am
NH11:09am

Think it's in the statement

BE11:09am

.... who only needed a decent rank in a Google search, rather than a business in the centre of town with gravestones in the window.

Mouselet bother, "dignity" is an awful name to google for, there are umpty-seven case studies on dignity in all things
NH11:09am

Initial reported deaths for 2017 were 590,000 and the Group conducted 68,800 funerals. Approximately 60 per cent were represented by traditional full service funerals at an average income of £3,800; seven per cent were simple funerals at an average income of £2,700; and approximately 27 per cent had been pre-arranged and the Group received an average income of £1,650. The remainder of the Group's volumes were contract and other low value funerals with an average income of £500. In each case, these amounts exclude disbursements. In addition, the division generates ancillary revenues equating to approximately £280 per funeral which are not expected to change materially.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

I see. So Dignity has, belatedly, responded to that. But the operational gearing on price cuts absolutely decimates earnings.

doeswalk @Mouselet part of the problem perhaps
NH11:10am

Yes, 50 per cent downgrades to EPS

BE11:10am

We wrote about it a little post the first (disguised) warning: https://www.ft.com...-aa33-c63fdc9b8c6c

SoS Need to have some vaccines that don't protect against all flus, that would put death rate up.. I had one at my local chemist which turned out to be the tri one - a friend told me I should have gone to boots which did the quad.
11:10 am
BE11:10am

There's also a terrific blogger on the sector, whom I'm sure the rabble can point me towards because I can't find the link immediately.

BE11:11am

Let me grab some sellside to show what's happening to forecasts.

Bonnemort Dignity sounds too much like a Swiss clinic for my liking
Mark Shapland Fevertree?
NH11:11am

I have an investec not somewhere

Soundbuy https://www.stockopedia.com/content/short-sell-report-published-on-dignity-plc-you-hold-uk-funeral-services-provider-220078/
Soundbuy BE above
Mouselet thanks!
11:12 am
NH11:12am

Here we go

Pseudonym Should be building a bridge to NI before another one to bloody France.
BE11:12am

(@Soundbuy: ta.)

NH11:12am

Dignity has announced a new pricing strategy, effective immediately, aimed at
slowing the market share declines that have become more pronounced in recent
years. Whilst the impact of the new strategy will take some months to determine,
the company anticipates significant switching from its traditional high end
product to its cheaper simple product. We adopt company switch assumptions
to lower FY18E sales by 12% and EPS by 52%, but provide a sensitivity analysis
to these assumptions. We expect the share price to be weak today.

11:12 am
NH11:12am

c.50% EPS downgrades: We lower FY18E sales by £41m or 12% to reflect the
new pricing strategy, which lowers funeral EBIT by the same amount. With
increased costs for digital investment, we lower PBT by 52%. Leaving all other
assumptions unchanged, we reduce EPS by 52%. For FY19E we anticipate a
modest increase in underlying deaths, but further market share losses and no
price rises (except for the pre-need product), consequently FY19E EPS falls 53%.

Pseudonym If anything another euro-tunnel to Germany to bypass the frogs if we must go south.
NH11:13am

We believe the new strategy effectively resets the base revenues
and profits for Dignity. Yet we feel that the longer term dynamics of the funeral
market are unchanged and believe the new pricing strategy should enable Dignity
to maintain market share over the longer term. The company should also be able
to streamline its cost base to yield margin improvements from FY19. Whilst we
anticipate significant weakness in the shares today, and acknowledge the
additional uncertainty until the impact of the new strategy can be assessed, we
continue to believe that Dignity offers defensive qualities over the longer term.
We lower our DCF derived target price to 1275p.

NH11:13am

Still a buyer

11:13 am
NH11:13am

So i presume they are house broker

BE11:13am

Hm............... Panmure similar, also still buying, also cutting by half.

Airborne Cigar @Pseudonym - maybe, but people actually want to go to France.
BE11:14am

This aggressive and decisive action will, in our view, provide a strong response to increasingly aggressive competition (from both Coop and others) that should, in due course, arrest the decline in DTY’s market share (14bps down on FY16) and, eventually, allow RPI level price rises to resume. Additionally, management is accelerating new services with digital marketing and brand strategies which will absorb an extra £2m pa of investment. This should allow DTY to replicate successes such as Simplicity Cremations (launched Nov’16) and currently averaging a run rate of 1,000 direct cremations pa

Lefevre These long bridges are a bad idea, bodies keep turning up on that one between Denmark & Sweden - as shown on BBC4
11:14 am
BE11:14am

The average reduction in the number of funerals per DTY
location per one thousand deaths (2004 – 2014) was 3.6%, but rose to 6.8% (2015-2017) and management now believes that this decline cannot be decelerated until FY19. We stress that this is not a unique DTY problem; from 2012-2016, we believe that Coop saw a comparable average reduction of 5.3% pa.

Boncoeur What about a cross channel zip wire?
Airborne Cigar The only reason to go to NI is for a pubcrawl, in which case you don't want to be driving...
Pseudonym They can already get to France in a variety of different ways.
BE11:15am

We cut our target price by c.50% to 1,410p based on highly-conservative assumptions of zero future price increases, a low 20% UFCF margin and no gain in market share. We expect c.£47m of UFCF in FY18, which we expect to grow driven by (a) strong crem and pre-paid markets (b) growth in UK deaths and (c) cost cutting to benefit margin. Prelims in Mar’18.

NH11:15am

Simplicity Cremations

11:14 am
NH11:15am

that looks interesting

NH11:15am

Design your own burial online

Airborne Cigar @Boncoeur - only if we can jam Boris on it
NH11:15am

Browse through our services page to help you decide which direct cremation package is right for you and whether you require any additional services for your loved one. If you're not sure then please call us and one of our advisors will be happy to help you.

Soundbuy DIY funerals never caught on........
Swedish chef Pseu: tunnels + Germans = mental picture of Steve McQueen on a Triumph motorcycle
11:15 am
BE11:16am

No suggestion here -- yet -- at this point that debt covenants are at risk ... but earnings are, what, 60 or 70% less than they were expected to be this time last year on what should be the most predictable business out there ........

Bonnemort Why not tunnels to Australia, NZ and Canada? I think Boris was just making smoke.
Pseudonym If we're sending Boris through it then I'd suggest a cannon.
NH11:16am

How much leverage does it have?

Flaneur DIY burials?
Boncoeur Boris zip wire https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=oxDwxNcURTU
BE11:16am

Net debt of just under £500m.

Tom Dalgleish Cheaper to do a Robert Maxwell
11:16 am
NH11:17am

hmmm

Pseudonym Actually, make that a cannon and a concrete wall.
BE11:17am

Against EBITDA of, what, £80m ish?

Forester Aside from price competition, interest in alternative funerals is much increased. Down my way, environmentally friendlywoodland burials etc are becoming very popular, even with "mainstream" elderly.
BE11:17am

Here's Peel Hunt.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Credit to management for taking aggressive action to react to
lower market share, but the consequences are significant. The
immediate impact on profits is obvious given the fixed price on
traditional funerals and 25% cut on low-cost funerals. However,
there is considerable uncertainty on the impact on volumes, mix
and competitor reaction. As a result our 46% cut to forecasts is
only a stab not clear view on the likely outcome.
There may be concern over the level of net debt and the ability
to fund the repayments – in our view this is not an issue as
Dignity will continue to generate healthy FCF enabling
repayment of debt and acquisitions. The share price reaction looks appropriate – at 950p the shares are trading on 13x our new forecasts.

NH11:17am

and its reputation as a utility type business destroyed

BE11:18am

It was rollup and a price gouger .......

Soundbuy 'friendlywoodland burials'..........not confusing that with fly tipping?
h1 How many times has dignity had profit warnings? @BE @NH
11:18 am
NH11:19am

and now it has a market cap lower than its net debt

NH11:19am

which is never a good sign

h1 Is this their first one?
BE11:19am

See the charts in this ML: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-11-16/

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(@h1: second, I think,)

chad_john Anything on Bon Marche please?
chad_john Rather large overreaction to an in-line statement, it seems.
BE11:20am

Earnings growth was entirely fee squeeze, which now unwinds.

Flaneur Hope they arent going under? etc..
BE11:20am

Anyway, is that enough death?

Tom Dalgleish Couple of rolled up listed funeral directors here in Oz. Awaiting the same eventually
11:20 am
NH11:20am

almost

NH11:21am

Talking of burials, will we soon be reading the last rites to Carpetright

Helen78 Is there any company who has issued more profit warnings than Carpetright : Prizes for anyone who can name a UK company that's had more profit warnings than Carpetright. First I can see was in 2003, then 2005, 2007, 2008, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2017 and now 2018.
undefined
VV75 anything on BT re the pension decision by the courts?
11:21 am
NH11:21am

That's down almost as much as Dignity

Swedish chef Talking of dying businesses, I note PFG retail bonds yield >8%.
Forester I invested in DTY when it first floated - good idea to have Tesco efficiency and buying behind the scenes, but local name over the door. Sold out when it became increasingly clear that they were becoming dependent on selling over-priced funeral plans
NH11:21am

which is some achievement

Carpetright PLC (CPR:LSE): Last: 93.00, down 71.5 (-43.47%), High: 104.00, Low: 85.00, Volume: 3.52m
Tom Dalgleish How come the Dignity market share problem happened suddenly?
11:22 am
NH11:22am

Can't say this is surprising

BE11:22am

The mystery, of course ,was always why Carpetright defied gravity in valuation terms.

BE11:22am

Not so much now.

11:22 am
NH11:22am

Does anyone buy carpet anymore?

Dante I doubt its sudden Tom - bet its been behind the scenes for several quarters
NH11:22am

I thought it was all fake wood floor

NH11:23am

and tiles

chad_john NH: they do rather fetching vinyl flooring too.
11:23 am
NH11:23am

moreover, the market for cheap lino is now what it was

Lefevre @Helen78, fair point, but it was well run in the early days of mid 90s by (?) Lord Harris. Just the craze for wood anti allergenic floors has been tough
Forester @Tom competition has been building from a variety of sources
BE11:23am

I dunno, Maybe they still have carpets in the provinces, or up north.

NH11:24am

possible I guess

11:24 am
BE11:24am

It's another "crazy operational gearing" story .......

Flaneur Retail numbers paint a grim picture overall.(Im a fan of Russel Napier who predicted all this and puts it down to demographics)
BE11:24am

Here's Peel Hunt again.

BE11:24am

That three weeks of post-Christmas trading can lead to a 57% to 86% reduction in PBT guidance is symptomatic of Carpetright's high operational gearing. Clearly, management is taking a view on the rest of the FY, but the scale of the cut is nonetheless remarkable. There were signs of pressure in the H1 results on 12 December, but current trade was at least in positive territory (+1.4% in 6wks to 9 Dec

Forester Made the mistake of buying (very cheap) CPR carpets for a hotel - terrible decision as showed footfall tracks within weeks!
Airborne Cigar @BE - same carpets we've had for 20 years - maybe I should reinvigorate the sector by buying a new one...
badger what's the deal with BT decision ?
11:24 am
NH11:25am

Hang on

BE11:25am

While the October/November trading period is important, the three weeks from Boxing Day are, we understand, typically three of the biggest consecutive weeks of trading in the year for Carpetright.
Management has seen a material reduction in footfall to stores which has translated into a reduction in transaction numbers (core flooring LFL sales down 7.1% since Christmas).

BE11:25am

.... Go on

11:25 am
NH11:25am

do people really finish gorging on turkey and mince pies

Lefevre Yes - carpets up North. Tiles too cold in the morning
NH11:25am

and think I really need a new carpet

NH11:25am

I can't believe it

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Apparently yes! Sofas also.

Forester Still need carpets in hotel otherwise noise issues on floors underneath etc
willosaurus I bought my first carpet recently. Fancy one. No regrets ... Feels like I now live in a comfy slippet!
Shinshin And function of reduced house sale volume too ? Rare to change carpet while still in same house I would think.
NH11:26am

Hmm strikes me the slowdown might have been visible a bit earlier

doeswalk maybe relatives spill red wine on the old one at christmas lunch
BE11:26am

.... Because what you want to do after being trapped with the family for 24 to 48 hours is go and buy big-ticket items with them.

Pseudonym @Forester Sounds more like you bought the cheapest rather than their fault.
Flaneur Maybe the govt should start a 'Help to Furnish' scheme?
Swedish chef A Junkers beech floor is being installed in my home as we speak. Hate carpets.
11:26 am
BE11:27am

No wonder Britain's divorce rate is so high. Anyway, back to Peel Hunt.

BE11:27am

We have to work hard to cut numbers to management's guided range. We now assume -3% UK LFL sales in H2 (+2% previously) and an 80bp gross margin reduction (-40bp previously). This leaves the UK at break-even in H2.
Management does not expect any issues with covenants on rebased numbers (the next quarterly review is in January). While we don't know the terms, covenants relate to leverage, fixed charge cover and capital expenditure. We estimate FY18E net debt/ EBITDA of 1.2x and EBIT fixed charge cover of 1.1x - we think cover must now be tight. We suspect that capex and working capital will need to be reduced in outer years if trading does not improve materially.

Gladys Leather floors are warm
Pseudonym We got a new carpet after xmas, it looked a better bet than getting the mince pie and turkey out of it.
rw42 @Lefevre - anti allergenic floors?
BE11:27am

It is hard to see what more management can do to turn the performance around. Equally, it is hard to see how the investment case could turn positive, given the high operational gearing, sales volatility and weak balance sheet. Our DCF-based valuation is highly sensitive to assumptions, but we reduce our TP from 138p to 42p, equating to a 4.6x FY19E PE, reflecting the high risks around the business. Maintain Sell.

Forester @pseudonym perhaps, but the quality of all their stock was very downmarket IMHO. You can buy better stuff at the same price online.
11:28 am
NH11:28am

There could be some busy ECM bankers in the Square Mile over the next six months or so.

BE11:28am

This seems to be the story of Christmas really ....

NH11:28am

Looks like they might need to raise money

11:28 am
NH11:28am

What was the story?

NH11:28am

high street woe?

NH11:28am

online OK?

Lefevre @rw42, just meant that wood floors supposed to be better for children with asthma - that was the view 20 years ago, fewer house dust mites
Pseudonym @Forester You pay something to be able to go have a look at it.
11:28 am
BE11:28am

In the sense that times are tough. Everyone's suffered a bit ....

NH11:29am

I see

NH11:29am

retail misery

Pinsticker In the good old bad old days, Carpetright was a decent indicator of the health of the housing market.
11:29 am
BE11:29am

High street's bad. But the ones suffering most are the ones with stale shop fleets that have been underinvested ..........

BE11:29am

.... and balance sheets that can't absorb the downturn in sales.

NH11:29am

That's running on the homepage at the moment

Noitche BT - High Court rules BT can not change to CPI (from RPI) for it's legacy pension plans. BT disappointed, considering position, may seek appeal.
GBKrona @badger - re:BT managers accepted moving to DC pension, waiting for others to do so. Pension deficit likely to reduce anyway as result of recalc (same as Tesco a few months ago). TV Premier League rights likely to reduce, as now have X-selling deal with Sky. New chairman (ex-RIO, SABM - both excellent investments). Therefore more cash to keep paying divs.
11:30 am
NH11:30am

UK retail sales posted the biggest fall since the direct aftermath of the 2016 Brexit referendum vote, with consumers feeling the pinch from rapidly rising prices and shifting some spending to November from December.

Forester @pseudonym learnt lesson that cheap carpet is a false economy. The hall/landing/stairways carpets are 25 years old and probably cost a bomb - but they still clean up as good as new despite heavy footfall
NH11:30am

Same story at Bonmarche I assume

Bonmarche Holdings PLC (BON:LSE): Last: 98.00, down 28.5 (-22.53%), High: 115.00, Low: 98.00, Volume: 516.61k
11:31 am
NH11:31am

Is this the posh baby clothes retailer?

NH11:31am

Or one for more generously proportioned people?

BE11:32am

The latter, I think. And the surprise is that the statement's meant to be reassuring.

11:32 am
NH11:32am

Let's have a look

rw42 @lefevre thanks - as an asthmatic that grew up in a house with carpet, this is somewhat interesting!
BE11:32am

They reckon they're on track to meet for the full-year.

BE11:32am

But H1's miserable. So it's hard to understand where that optimism is coming from.

Flaneur Can never fathom this 'rapidly rising prices' yet 'inflation falling' stuff that the media push. Must be one or the other surely?
11:33 am
NH11:33am

Given what we have seen elsewhere, seems a touch Panglossian

Lefevre @Noitche, re CPI/RPI. Story yesterday from Chris Giles in FT about ONS cock up on telecoms pricing, suggesting RPI too high : The error, which covers the period from 2010-2015, means that inflation statistics may have been significantly too high and economic growth figures too low, calling into question the consumer price index and retail price index,"
BE11:33am

Investec incoming.

BE11:34am

Better gross margin delivered at the expense of sales. Despite the difficult trading backdrop, management stuck to a more full-price sales/less discounting strategy for the second year in a row. As a result, gross margin improved but at a cost to sales. BON reported Q3 sales down 5.5% with LFL including online down 6.9% vs INVe H2 +2.9%.
 Online performance stood out (Q3 +28.5%), delivering a third quarter of +30% growth. Store LFL down 9.7% with no benefit seen from the colder weather/snow in December as BON’s customers tend to stay at home.

Pseudonym I don't get the impression that GDP has been understated...
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Efficiencies and tight cost control means guiding to FY18 PBT in line with previous expectations assuming no material change in market conditions.
Company-compiled consensus FY18 PBT is £8m vs INVe £8.5m. Lower costs due to non-repeat of last year’s TV advertising & Head Office restructuring costs together with online marketing, logistics and store operating efficiencies.
 Cut FY18e and FY19e PBT by 6% and 5% respectively. Our forecasts assume positive Q4 sales and gross margin decline [...]. We maintain FY19e growth assumptions, but off a lower FY18e base

Lefevre @rw42 - had a sister who researched that to death when her youngest was diagnosed with asthma
BE11:35am

Valuation (CY18 PE 8.7x; DPS yield 6%) undemanding given solid balance sheet & self-help opportunities. While the shares are likely to react to the scale of the sales decline short term, we believe progress from the self-help strategy is evident. A more flexible business model is emerging. Further progress likely in FY19 with focus on more buying improvement, operating efficiencies, digital & driving loyalty. TP maintained with downgrade offset by peers re-rating.

Bonnemort @Lefevre - what are the implications for past pension payments (increases linked to RPI)?
NH11:35am

That nicely sums things up. Downturn in shops sales spooks investors.

11:35 am
NH11:36am

I think that's probably enough retail misery for one day

undefined
NH11:36am

shall we have a look at the wider market?

rw42 @Lefevre - parent's pet theory was the heating system in the house where i was born - some sort of hot air ducted system that they reckon left a lot of dust airborn, rather than central heating with radiators etc! Asthma is fine these days, still have pet allergies though!
nichoman IWG going down to the wire...
11:36 am
NH11:37am

What's happening?

BE11:37am

We're edging higher, but hard to pick up much in the way of themes.

BE11:37am

In terms of what's been mentioned on the right ......

NH11:37am

US 10-yield edging up

NH11:37am

I'm watching that

Soundbuy Esure - robust vols on update......in play (again)?

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Sterling trying to get through $1.40.

NH11:38am

crikey will be safe to go on holiday in the US soon

Lefevre @Bonnemort - that's a good question, "the agency would seek to correct the errors in the national accounts in 2019, but had to think hard about how widespread the changes should be." https://www.ft.com/content/abc14c66-fb78-11e7-a492-2c9be7f3120a.
BE11:39am

Assuming we're still allowed in.

11:39 am
NH11:39am

Before we address some of the themes mentioned by the ROTR

NH11:39am

I feel must address the front page of the Times

NH11:39am

because I'm not sure where it came from

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Uh-oh.

Dante Whats your view on oil Neil? is $70 as high as we hit?
NH11:40am

ICYMI

NH11:40am

this was the splash

11:40 am
NH11:40am

White-collar criminals are acting with impunity, with fewer than ten prosecutions for insider trading in the past five years, an investigation has found.
A freedom of information request to the chief City watchdog revealed how little was being done to stop stock market abuse despite research by The Times suggesting the system was being exploited.
The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has prosecuted eight cases of insider trading in the past five years and secured 12 convictions. By comparison, the Department for Work and Pensions prosecuted or penalised more than 10,000 benefit fraudsters last year. Yet large numbers of investors appear to be receiving and benefiting from confidential information from inside FTSE-listed companies.

BE11:40am

........... hm.

imp did I read somewhere that we might hear some SKY bid news soon?
NH11:40am

I was particularly drawn to this line

Flaneur Anyone tell me where this US oil is coming from; is it shale or crude?
11:40 am
NH11:41am

In some cases gangs leak bid rumours to websites, bulletin boards or newspapers before buying shares so they can cite the article or post as the reason for their trading activity if they are caught.

DJ please could you share the BAML downgrade of JD Sports yesterday?
BE11:41am

............... uh.

NH11:41am

if only because

DRichi @Dante- Malcy's estimate is $75 at YE
11:41 am
NH11:41am

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Fever-Tree's performance to date has been impressive. The company effectively
created the premium mixers category, giving consumers more choice and a higher
quality product, with better cash margins for the on-trade and a high rate of
sales in the retail channel. Drawing on our extensive channel checking, we expect
the premiumisation of mixers to continue and see Fever-Tree as well placed to
capitalise on this growth despite increased competition.

BE11:51am

The penetration of premium mixers is currently 9% of the total mixers market
versus 33% for premium spirits, the closest proxy for mixers. Our industry model
assumes further penetration of premium mixers, driving a ~20% CAGR 2017-25
across Fever-Tree's core markets. This growth underpins our forecasts for 23%
revenue CAGR, 20% EBITDA CAGR and 20% EPS CAGR between FY17-20

What does this mean for the stock? In our view, the worse it gets for Bunge
fundamentally in 2018, the higher the probability of the board opening the door for a
strategic acquirer. The standstill agreement with Glencore will expire “early in 2018”
according to the Wall Street Journal. We would not be surprised to see Glencore make a
more formal overture soon after Bunge releases results on February 13.
Valuation. To get to our target price of $84/share, we place a 50% probability on the
chances of the stock getting to $90/share through a Glencore take-out and a 50%
probability on the stock getting to $78/share in 12 months independently. Our fundamental
valuation excluding a take-out assumes a 15.6x P/E multiple (in line with peers ADM and

NH12:02pm

The International Energy Agency revised higher its US oil production growth forecasts for 2018, stressing that rapidly expanding shale output is a major factor offsetting Opec-led supply cuts. The latest body to raise estimates, following the US energy department’s statistics arm and Opec’s own research unit, the IEA said: “this year promises to be a record-setting one for the US.

12:02 pm
NH12:02pm

Production growth, the IEA said in its monthly market report, was returning “to the heady days of 2013-2015” with US total output on course to overtake Saudi Arabia and rivalling Russia. Still, the oil market will be broadly in balance this year. Big producer nations have feared a price rebound in recent weeks — to a 2014 high of around $70 a barrel — could spur a flood of new shale oil supply, undermining efforts by global producers to curb output.

NH12:05pm

Today’s IEA monthly report (OMR) has confirmed our earlier assessment that the surplus in total OECD company stocks vs. the 5-year average fell sharply in the last two months of last year.

The IEA has assessed, on the basis of provisional data, that the surplus in total OECD company stocks vs. the 5-year average fell to only 90 mmb at end-November. It has also now extended its assessment a month further than previously, estimating in today’s OMR (on the basis of preliminary data for the main OECD areas) that the end-December surplus fell even further, to only 68 mmb.

12:05 pm
NH12:06pm

These IEA figures match almost exactly our assessment in our latest monthly update, released last week, that put the OECD stocks surplus at 92 mmb at end-November and 76 mmb at end-December (see World Oil Market Report - Global Oil Market Drivers - 10 January 2018).

More importantly, the IEA has confirmed our view that the stocks surplus is now much smaller than estimated by OPEC. In its latest monthly report yesterday, OPEC estimated that the stocks surplus at end-November was still at 133 mmb – much higher than the FGE/IEA assessments of some 90 mmb.
